articles.headline: A Kingdom Still Whole, but Far From United
articles.snippet: A debate over regional and national autonomy set off by Scotland’s failed referendum on independence has just begun, promising a constitutional shake-up in the United Kingdom.
articles.abstract: A debate over regional and national autonomy set off by Scotland’s failed referendum on independence has just begun, promising a constitutional shake-up in the United Kingdom.
articles.lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — Scotland chose decisively against independence on Thursday, but it was not a vote for the status quo in Britain.

articles.headline: Big Factories Go to Work on Biofuel
articles.snippet: One commercial plant opened this month and two others are close, but technical and economic hurdles remain.
articles.abstract: One commercial plant opened this month and two others are close, but technical and economic hurdles remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: EMMETSBURG, Iowa — Charlie Kollasch, a farmer supplying raw material to a huge new ethanol factory here, stood inside a big red shed on his property, showing off the V-shaped metal frame studded with prongs that he and his son had installed on top of a flatbed truck.

articles.headline: A Soaring Debut for Alibaba
articles.snippet: The Chinese Internet giant, which raised $21.8 billion in its stock sale, instantly became one of the biggest publicly traded technology companies in the world.
articles.abstract: The Chinese Internet giant, which raised $21.8 billion in its stock sale, instantly became one of the biggest publicly traded technology companies in the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: The long-awaited public market debut of the Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet titan, did not disappoint on Friday, eclipsing every other company that has started to sell stock so far this year.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Democrats Pin Senate Hopes on a Kansan
articles.snippet: The Senate race in Kansas has become the most scrutinized contest in the country, with Republicans scrambling to protect the incumbent and Democrats putting their hopes on an independent.
articles.abstract: The Senate race in Kansas has become the most scrutinized contest in the country, with Republicans scrambling to protect the incumbent and Democrats putting their hopes on an independent.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — The Senate race in Kansas may suddenly be the most crucial contest in the country. Republicans are scrambling to protect a longtime incumbent. Bob Dole is back on the campaign trail. The state’s Democrats have no candidate and are trying to say as little about that as possible. And a 45-year-old investor from suburban Kansas City may hold the key to control of the Senate in January.

articles.headline: Ex-Employees Say Home Depot Left Data Vulnerable
articles.snippet: Before a major data breach, Home Depot was slow to raise its defenses against hackers despite alarms from security experts as far back as 2008.
articles.abstract: Before a major data breach, Home Depot was slow to raise its defenses against hackers despite alarms from security experts as far back as 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: The risks were clear to computer experts inside Home Depot: The home improvement chain, they warned for years, might be easy prey for hackers.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: A Writerly Chill at Jeff Bezos’ Campfire
articles.snippet: Every fall, Jeff Bezos of Amazon hosts a literary weekend on condition that writers not discuss the event. Now Amazon’s battle with Hachette is sapping some of the good will.
articles.abstract: Every fall, Jeff Bezos of Amazon hosts a literary weekend on condition that writers not discuss the event. Now Amazon’s battle with Hachette is sapping some of the good will.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jeff Bezos tells writers to keep quiet, they obey.

articles.headline: A Florida Race Strains Wallets and Loyalties
articles.snippet: The contest for governor between Rick Scott, the incumbent, and Charlie Crist, who switched parties, is costing tens of millions of dollars and disorienting voters.
articles.abstract: The contest for governor between Rick Scott, the incumbent, and Charlie Crist, who switched parties, is costing tens of millions of dollars and disorienting voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — When Bill Clinton attended a recent campaign rally for his party’s candidate for governor here, he whipped up the crowd with keystone Democratic issues — higher wages, better-funded schools and affordable health care.

articles.headline: Slamming a Door on Hedge Funds
articles.snippet: Critics of public pensions’ investments in hedge funds received a big boost when Calpers said it would divest its $4 billion portfolio of such funds over the next year.
articles.abstract: Critics of public pensions’ investments in hedge funds received a big boost when Calpers said it would divest its $4 billion portfolio of such funds over the next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Are public pension funds over their crush on hedge funds?

articles.headline: Zenefits’ Leader Is Rattling an Industry, So Why Is He Stressed Out?
articles.snippet: Parker Conrad’s start-up, which helps small businesses navigate employee benefits, has shown phenomenal growth. Yet he is anything but sure of its success.
articles.abstract: Parker Conrad’s start-up, which helps small businesses navigate employee benefits, has shown phenomenal growth. Yet he is anything but sure of its success.
articles.lead_paragraph: Parker Conrad’s start-up, Zenefits, is thought to be one of the fastest-growing companies in recent Silicon Valley history, and his investors and associates describe him as an uncommonly talented software visionary. But lately, Mr. Conrad often finds himself petrified, his days a series of white-knuckled attempts to escape the clutches of sudden, inadvertent failure.

articles.headline: In Scotland and Beyond, a Crisis of Faith in the Global Elite
articles.snippet: The independence movement in Scotland was another sign of widespread dissatisfaction with an established order that has failed to deliver.
articles.abstract: The independence movement in Scotland was another sign of widespread dissatisfaction with an established order that has failed to deliver.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Scotland this week, a measure to become an independent country and end the United Kingdom as we know it failed, but it would have succeeded with a swing of just 5 percent of the vote. Earlier in the week, a right-wing anti-immigration party in Sweden claimed its largest-ever share of parliamentary votes. And in the United States, new census data released this week showed that middle-income American families made 8 percent less last year, adjusted for inflation, than they did in 2007.

articles.headline: After Surgery, Surprise $117,000 Medical Bill From Doctor He Didn’t Know
articles.snippet: In a growing practice, medical assistants, consultants and other hospital staffers, often called in without patients’ knowledge, are charging hefty fees.
articles.abstract: In a growing practice, medical assistants, consultants and other hospital staffers, often called in without patients’ knowledge, are charging hefty fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before his three-hour neck surgery for herniated disks in December, Peter Drier, 37, signed a pile of consent forms. A bank technology manager who had researched his insurance coverage, Mr. Drier was prepared when the bills started arriving: $56,000 from Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan, $4,300 from the anesthesiologist and even $133,000 from his orthopedist, who he knew would accept a fraction of that fee.

articles.headline: U.S. Suspects More Direct Threats Beyond ISIS
articles.snippet: A Syrian group led by a former member of Osama bin Laden’s inner circle is seen as more dangerous than the Islamic State for its potential to launch terror attacks.
articles.abstract: A Syrian group led by a former member of Osama bin Laden’s inner circle is seen as more dangerous than the Islamic State for its potential to launch terror attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the United States begins what could be a lengthy military campaign against the Islamic State, intelligence and law enforcement officials said another Syrian group, led by a shadowy figure who was once among Osama bin Laden’s inner circle, posed a more direct threat to America and Europe.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Michael S. Schmidt and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: After Rancor, Afghans Agree to Share Power
articles.snippet: After eight months of enmity over the protracted presidential election, Ashraf Ghani and Abdullah Abdullah will have to confront the challenges of jointly governing their country.
articles.abstract: After eight months of enmity over the protracted presidential election, Ashraf Ghani and Abdullah Abdullah will have to confront the challenges of jointly governing their country.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Their campaign workers traded blows over ballot boxes during an election widely seen as fraudulent. Some of the warlords backing them have muttered about starting a parallel government, a potential recipe for civil war in Afghanistan. And they’ve just come out of a vote so discredited that some officials don’t want the final tallies announced.

articles.headline: China Clamps Down on Web, Pinching Companies Like Google
articles.snippet: Chinese authorities have tightened censorship over Internet traffic in recent weeks, and Google and its services are particularly affected.
articles.abstract: Chinese authorities have tightened censorship over Internet traffic in recent weeks, and Google and its services are particularly affected.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Google’s problems in China just got worse.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Warner Bros., After Shake-Up and Shaky Summer, Digs In
articles.snippet: Over a year into a shake-up that put Kevin Tsujihara in the chief executive’s seat at Warner, the studio has yet to find its footing.
articles.abstract: Over a year into a shake-up that put Kevin Tsujihara in the chief executive’s seat at Warner, the studio has yet to find its footing.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — Summer was brutal at Warner Bros., and not just because the thermometer hit 105 degrees on its sun-scorched lot here last week.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Soldiers’ Graves Bear Witness to Russia’s Role in Ukraine
articles.snippet: Even as the Kremlin tries to deny its involvement and families are pressured to keep quiet, the deaths of soldiers sent to fight in Ukraine are impossible to ignore.
articles.abstract: Even as the Kremlin tries to deny its involvement and families are pressured to keep quiet, the deaths of soldiers sent to fight in Ukraine are impossible to ignore.
articles.lead_paragraph: SELIZOVO, Russia — In a far corner of a small cemetery outside this tiny village by the Oka River, a black flag proclaiming the military might of Russia’s tank forces ripples in the wind above the recently dug grave of Sgt. Vladislav A. Barakov. A photograph of the baby-faced soldier in full dress uniform sits propped against a wooden cross with a small plaque that says he died on Aug. 24. He was 21.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Alexandra Odynova

articles.headline: Fall TV Season Has Buzz, but It’s Growing Softer
articles.snippet: Although cable and online television are making inroads on the network television season system, it remains intact, driven by economic factors and the struggle to determine what shows are strongest.
articles.abstract: Although cable and online television are making inroads on the network television season system, it remains intact, driven by economic factors and the struggle to determine what shows are strongest.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a throwback, an archaic model, a vestige of a fading business. So why does a ripple of excitement continue to surround the start of another television season?
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Emily Steel

articles.headline: U.S. Ramping Up Major Renewal in Nuclear Arms
articles.snippet: An expansion comes under a president who campaigned for “a nuclear-free world” and made disarmament a main goal of American defense policy.
articles.abstract: An expansion comes under a president who campaigned for “a nuclear-free world” and made disarmament a main goal of American defense policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A sprawling new plant here in a former soybean field makes the mechanical guts of America’s atomic warheads. Bigger than the Pentagon, full of futuristic gear and thousands of workers, the plant, dedicated last month, modernizes the aging weapons that the United States can fire from missiles, bombers and submarines.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: In Tense Woods, Pennsylvania State Police Shift From Prey to Hunters
articles.snippet: After one of their own was killed and another wounded, law enforcement officers have taken to the Pennsylvania forest to find the person responsible.
articles.abstract: After one of their own was killed and another wounded, law enforcement officers have taken to the Pennsylvania forest to find the person responsible.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANADENSIS, Pa. — The Pennsylvania State Police recommend that you remain in your homes. That you not go into the surrounding woods. That you lock all doors and vehicles, keep the exterior of your home well lit, and if you see a shed open that you remember having closed, report it immediately.

articles.headline: Publications See Pinterest as Key Ally
articles.snippet: Magazines like Better Homes and Gardens and Self increasingly see the photo-sharing site as a critical source of traffic — and emerging trends to cover.
articles.abstract: Magazines like Better Homes and Gardens and Self increasingly see the photo-sharing site as a critical source of traffic — and emerging trends to cover.
articles.lead_paragraph: Autumn is not yet upon us, but Jill Waage, a top editor at Better Homes and Gardens, has already predicted some of the biggest trends of the coming holidays. Painted pumpkins are about to replace carved pumpkins. Snowman cookies with jiggly eyes will overtake traditional gingerbread men. And decorative ribbons on Christmas presents are going to get much more creative.

articles.headline: First-Weekend Sales of Apple’s iPhone 6 Models Top 10 Million
articles.snippet: The strong demand for Apple’s new devices mirrors growing consumer interest in smartphones with bigger screens.
articles.abstract: The strong demand for Apple’s new devices mirrors growing consumer interest in smartphones with bigger screens.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple’s investors obsess over early iPhone sales like Hollywood producers tracking opening ticket sales for a blockbuster movie.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Charles Plosser and Richard Fisher, Both Dissenters, to Retire From Fed
articles.snippet: Charles Plosser, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, said that he would retire in March. Richard Fisher, president of the Federal Reserve of Dallas, is required to step down in April.
articles.abstract: Charles Plosser, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, said that he would retire in March. Richard Fisher, president of the Federal Reserve of Dallas, is required to step down in April.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two Federal Reserve officials who have warned loudly and persistently that the Fed is overreaching in its economic stimulus campaign plan to retire next year after completing terms on the Fed’s policy-making committee.
